@mod_taharok wrote:

The reason I wanted to do a range was because in my learn java book it said to make a chess script for practice and to do that I figured I needed to do a maximum number of players variable that covered a wide range.

Perhaps you could use an array or a Collection to store the range of variables?

item.title: Java programming help
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“dogzound5@gmail.com, post:5, topic:264885”]Thanks for helping me understand. I had one question though. If I set up an int to = anything up to its max how would I write that out?? I don’t want it to be equal to a number. ex int plays = 5;

I want it to be able to represent any number up to its max amount it can represent. [br][br][size=1]Posted on: February 28, 2009, 12:22:10 pm[/size][hr]Would I just set it as int plays; ??[/quote]
I don’t really understand what you mean. What you could do is something like this

int maximum = 1000;
int number = 10;
// do some things with number here...
if(number < maximum) // if number is less than maxiumum (1000), then do this:
{
// do something...
}
else // the number is greater than maximum (1000) do this:
{
// do something...
}

Read full topic

item.title: Java programming help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“dogzound5@gmail.com, post:5, topic:264885”]Thanks for helping me understand. I had one question though. If I set up an int to = anything up to its max how would I write that out?? I don’t want it to be equal to a number. ex int plays = 5;

I want it to be able to represent any number up to its max amount it can represent. [br][br][size=1]Posted on: February 28, 2009, 12:22:10 pm[/size][hr]Would I just set it as int plays; ??[/quote]

If you don’t define a variable, Java defines it for you with the default values. The default values are based upon the implementation, but are generally 0 for all numerical datatypes and false for the boolean datatype. For objects, the default value is [tt]null[/tt].

A number can only have one given value, not many. Why do you want to store a range anyway?

Read full topic

item.title: Java programming help
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

public class Board {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		new Board();	
	}

	int spaces = 100;
	int pieces = 50;
	boolean turn = true || false;
	
	public Board() {
		//what you want it to do when it starts
	}

	void moveForward() {
		if (pieces > 0 && turn == true) {
			System.out
					.println("One of the chess pieces has been moved from initial starting point...One has been deducted");
			System.out.println("One space of the board has been moved");
		}
	}

	void moveBackward() {
		if (pieces > 0 && turn == true) {
			System.out.println("You have moved back spaces");
		}
	}
}

You cant declare a method in the body of another.

Read full topic

item.title: Java programming help
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

You can’t initialize methods inside of other methods.

Read full topic

item.title: Java programming help
item.dc:creator: @dogzound5 dogzound5@gmail.com
item.description:
@dogzound5 wrote:

I was writing a little chess script for some practice and received moethod errors and illegal start of expressions. If you could look at my code and tell me what I did wrong. I have checked it four times and tried to fix but everything I do another error comes up.

[code]public class board {

public static void main(String[] args) {
			
	int spaces = 100;
	int pieces = 50;
	boolean turn = true || false;

		void moveForward() {
			if(pieces > 0 && turn == true) { 
				System.out.println("One of the chess pieces has been moved from initial starting point...One has been deducted");
				System.out.println("One space of the board has been moved");
				}
			}
		void moveBackward() {				
			if(pieces > 0 && turn == true) { 
				System.out.println("You have moved back spaces");
				}
			}
			
	}

}
[/code]

Here is sub class.

public class playerOne extends board {
	
			void playerPlays() {
				System.out.println("Player begins playing...");
				
			moveBackward();
			moveForward();
			}

}

Read full topic
